data.q: What is the main characteristic of Static Site Generation (SSG)?
o: The HTML is generated on the server for every single request
The HTML is generated at build time and served as pre-rendered files
The page is rendered entirely in the browser using JavaScript
The site requires a live database connection to display any content
data.e: SSG produces static HTML files during the build process. These files can be hosted on a CDN, making them extremely fast and secure.

data.q: When is Server-Side Rendering (SSR) preferred over Static Site Generation (SSG)?
o: When the content is the same for every user
When the page contains highly dynamic data that changes on every request
When you want the absolute fastest Time to First Byte (TTFB)
When you don't have access to a server
data.e: SSR is ideal for pages with personalized data (like a user dashboard) or frequently updating data that must be fresh for every visit.

data.q: What does 'Hydration' refer to in the context of SSR/SSG?
o: The process of cleaning up unused CSS files
The process of attaching event listeners to static HTML to make it interactive
Converting a database schema into JSON
Compressing images for faster mobile loading
data.e: After the browser receives the static HTML, the JavaScript bundle 'hydrates' the page, allowing React/Vue/etc. to take over and handle user interactions.

o: A way to rebuild the entire site every time a user visits
A strategy to update specific static pages in the background without a full rebuild
A method for rendering pages only when the user scrolls
A CSS optimization technique
data.e: ISR allows you to keep the benefits of static files while enabling updates to content at specific intervals or on-demand, without re-deploying the whole site.

data.q: In a Next.js application, which function is used to fetch data for Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
o: getStaticProps
getServerSideProps
getInitialData
useEffect
data.e: `getServerSideProps` runs on every request on the server side to fetch data and pass it to the component as props.

data.q: What is a major SEO advantage of SSR over a standard Client-Side Rendered (CSR) SPA?
o: It makes the website files smaller
It provides a fully rendered HTML document for search engine crawlers to index immediately
It automatically generates meta tags for social media
It prevents Google from seeing the JavaScript code
data.e: While search engines have improved at indexing JS, providing a full HTML response is more reliable and ensures all content is visible to every crawler.

data.q: Which of the following is a drawback of traditional Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
o: Poor SEO
Slower Time to First Byte (TTFB) compared to SSG
No support for JavaScript
Inability to use CSS
data.e: Because the server must generate the HTML for every request, the initial response time is usually slower than serving a pre-built file from a CDN.

data.q: What is the 'Flash of Unstyled Content' (FOUC) often associated with in poor SSR implementations?
o: The background color changing randomly
A brief moment where raw HTML is visible before CSS or JS is applied
The browser crashing due to memory leaks
Images appearing as broken icons
data.e: FOUC happens if the HTML is rendered but the styles are loaded late or the JS hasn't yet hydrated the components.

data.q: Which tool is specifically famous for popularized Static Site Generation for React?
o: Gatsby
Express
Redux
Angular
data.e: Gatsby was a pioneer in the 'JAMstack' movement, using GraphQL and React to build highly optimized static websites.

data.q: What does 'Client-Side Rendering' (CSR) primarily rely on to show content?
o: Pre-built HTML files
A JavaScript bundle that builds the UI in the browser
A server that sends fully formed pages
A direct connection to a SQL database
data.e: In CSR, the server sends a nearly empty HTML file and a JS script. The browser then executes the script to fetch data and render the page.

o: Loading only half of the CSS
Hydrating only the interactive components while leaving the rest as static HTML
A method to hydrate the page only on mobile devices
Storing the state of the app in the cloud
data.e: Islands architecture (used by frameworks like Astro) reduces the amount of JavaScript sent to the browser by only making necessary parts interactive.

data.q: Which environment is required to host an SSR application compared to an SSG one?
o: A simple file storage (like S3)
A live Node.js or similar server environment
A specialized CSS compiler
Only a browser is needed
data.e: SSG can be hosted on 'dumb' static hosting. SSR requires a 'smart' server or serverless functions to run the code and generate HTML on the fly.
